title: When the World Feels Too Loud
body: It’s not that you're broken — it's that your system was asked to carry too much input without enough space to process. You’re not weak. You’re saturated.
echo_intro: If the world’s felt too loud lately, this might be for you.

title: Withdrawal is Not Weakness
body: Pulling away from noise, people, or light isn’t giving up. It’s your nervous system protecting itself the only way it knows how. Let it rest.
echo_intro: When withdrawal shows up, this might help soften it.

title: Small Things That Break the Camel
body: It’s not just the big things. It’s the flickering light, the overlapping voices, the background tension. Your response is valid, even when the trigger seems small.
echo_intro: You’re not overreacting — your system is saturated.

title: Reduce, Don’t Escape
body: Lower the lights. Turn down the sound. Breathe slower than you think you need. You don’t have to leave — you just need to shrink the space around you.
echo_intro: This one’s for when you need less, not more.

title: Take Five Seconds
body: Set a five-second timer. That’s all. Close your eyes. Let your body be here, nowhere else. The world can wait. You can’t.
echo_intro: Try this if everything feels too much all at once.

title: You’re Not Behind — You’re Full
body: If you can’t cry, speak, or focus — it’s not that you’re behind. It’s that your system is full. Processing can wait. Safety comes first.
echo_intro: This card is here to make space, not demand clarity.

title: Noise Doesn’t Have to Win
body: Every beep, buzz, or interruption chips away at your ability to stay present. It’s not your fault that modern life overwhelms your nervous system. It was built that way. You weren’t.
echo_intro: For when it all feels like too much input from too many places.

title: Too Tired to Sleep, Too Alert to Rest
body: You’re not wired wrong. Sometimes a nervous system stuck in high alert can’t power down, even when exhaustion hits. That’s not failure — it’s dysregulated protection.
echo_intro: For when you're spinning too fast to land.

title: Not All Danger Is Loud
body: You might not hear a threat — but your body does. The hum of tension in your shoulders, your jaw, your breath? That’s not random. It’s memory.
echo_intro: Sometimes tension means 'I'm still holding something.'

title: Multitasking Is a Lie
body: Your brain wasn’t made to hold ten threads at once. Switching gears drains fuel. No wonder you're tired. You're not unproductive — you’re overloaded.
echo_intro: You’re not failing at life. You’re juggling too many realities.

title: You’re Not Meant to Absorb It All
body: Scrolling, pinging, messaging, remembering — no wonder your thoughts feel cluttered. Your nervous system needs space between signals. You deserve stillness.
echo_intro: A pause might be the medicine here.

title: Too Much on the Skin
body: You’re not dramatic for hating the tags, the heat, the clothes that don’t feel right. Your skin is trying to talk to you — and you’re allowed to listen.
echo_intro: This is for the body that feels too much, too fast.

title: Tiny Things Still Drain You
body: It's not weakness. It’s accumulation. Every ding, beep, and interruption pulls energy away — even when you pretend it doesn’t. You’re not imagining it.
echo_intro: Here if your brain feels threadbare after nothing 'big.'

title: Silence Isn’t Boring — It’s Medicine
body: Your system might crave silence but be afraid of it too. That’s okay. Let stillness be a soft room — not a punishment. You’re allowed to retreat.
echo_intro: When silence scares you — and heals you — this might help.

title: After the Storm
body: What came after the meltdown wasn’t weakness. It was the natural crash of a body protecting itself too long. You’re not broken — just overstretched.
echo_intro: For post-overload shame or confusion.

title: It’s Not That You’re Angry — You’re Fried
body: The sharp snap, the flare, the tight words — they’re not moral failures. They’re signs that your nervous system is maxed. Recovery starts with naming that truth.
echo_intro: This is for the moment after something sharp escapes you.

title: Clutter Isn’t Just Around You
body: Messy room. Messy tabs. Messy thoughts. It’s not laziness — it’s visual input echoing into mental overload. Your system’s drowning in too many open loops.
echo_intro: If you're stuck between tabs, piles, or decisions — try this.

title: It’s Okay to Plan Your Exits
body: Needing to know where the exits are doesn’t mean you’re antisocial. It means you’re trying to survive the noise. That’s wise. That’s strategy. Not failure.
echo_intro: For those who plan how to leave — not to quit, but to breathe.

title: Step Away Without Apology
body: You’re allowed to pause mid-conversation, leave the room, take five minutes in the bathroom. Your body isn’t abandoning others — it’s returning to itself.
echo_intro: Try this before pushing through the next wave.

title: Noise-Cancelling Is a Form of Boundary
body: Earplugs. Sunglasses. Screens down. These aren’t escape — they’re protection. You’re not antisocial. You’re learning how to stay whole.
echo_intro: This is your reminder that protection ≠ avoidance.
